**Russell Conwell Hoban** (February 4, 1925 – December 13, 2011) was an [American](/wiki/Americans "Americans") writer. His works span many genres, including [fantasy](/wiki/Fantasy "Fantasy"), [science fiction](/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction"), mainstream [fiction](/wiki/Fiction "Fiction"), [magical realism](/wiki/Magical_realism "Magical realism"), [poetry](/wiki/Poetry "Poetry"), and [children's books](/wiki/Children%27s_books "Children's books").
He lived in London from 1969 until his death.

Biography
---------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Russell_Hoban&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Biography")]

Hoban was born in [Lansdale, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Lansdale,_Pennsylvania "Lansdale, Pennsylvania"), just outside [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania "Philadelphia, Pennsylvania"), to [Jewish](/wiki/Jew "Jew") immigrants from [Ostrog](/wiki/Ostroh "Ostroh") (now in [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine")). His father, Abram T. Hoban, was the advertising manager of the [Yiddish-language](/wiki/Yiddish "Yiddish") *[Jewish Daily Forward](/wiki/The_Forward "The Forward")* and the director of The Drama Guild of the Labor Institute of the [Workmen's Circle](/wiki/Workmen%27s_Circle "Workmen's Circle") of Philadelphia.[[4]](#cite_note-PA_Center_for_the_Book-4) His father died when Russell was 11, and Russell was thereafter raised by his mother, Jeanette Dimmerman. He was named for [Russell Conwell](/wiki/Russell_Conwell "Russell Conwell").[[4]](#cite_note-PA_Center_for_the_Book-4) After briefly attending [Temple University](/wiki/Temple_University "Temple University"), he enlisted in the [Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army") at age 18 and served in the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") and Italy as a radio operator during World War II, earning a [bronze star](/wiki/Bronze_star "Bronze star").[[3]](#cite_note-weber-3) During his military service he married [Lillian Aberman](/wiki/Lillian_Hoban "Lillian Hoban"), who later became a writer and illustrator herself. They had four children before divorcing in 1975.

After leaving military service, Hoban worked as an [illustrator](/wiki/Illustration "Illustration"), painting several covers for *[TIME](/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")*, *[Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")*, and *[The Saturday Evening Post](/wiki/The_Saturday_Evening_Post "The Saturday Evening Post")*, and as an [advertising](/wiki/Advertising "Advertising") [copywriter](/wiki/Copywriter "Copywriter")—occupations which several of his characters later shared—before he wrote and illustrated his first children's book, *What Does It Do and How Does It Work?: Power Shovel, Dump Truck, and Other Heavy Machines*, published by [Harper](/wiki/Harper_(publisher) "Harper (publisher)") in 1959.[[5]](#cite_note-LCC-5) His 1962 *Time* cover portrait of [Joan Baez](/wiki/Joan_Baez "Joan Baez") now hangs in the [US National Portrait Gallery](/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery_(United_States) "National Portrait Gallery (United States)"). [[1]](https://npg.si.edu/object/npg_NPG.78.TC215)

The note "About the Artist" in the Macmillan Classics Edition of *Tales and Poems of [Edgar Allan Poe](/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe "Edgar Allan Poe")* (second printing 1965), which Hoban illustrated, notes that he worked in advertising for [Batten Barton Durstine & Osborn](/wiki/BBDO "BBDO") and that he later became the art director of [J. Walter Thompson](/wiki/J._Walter_Thompson "J. Walter Thompson"): "Heavy machinery later became subjects for his paintings, and this led him into the children's book field with the writing and illustrating of *What Does It Do and How Does It Work?* and *The Atomic Submarine*." That note also points out that in 1964, at the time the book's illustrations were copyrighted, Hoban was teaching drawing at the [School of Visual Arts](/wiki/School_of_Visual_Arts "School of Visual Arts") in New York City, collaborating with his first wife on their fifth children's book, and living in [Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut "Connecticut").

Hoban wrote exclusively for children for the next decade, and came to be known best for the series of seven picture books that feature Frances, a temperamental badger girl[[3]](#cite_note-weber-3) whose escapades were based partly on the experiences of his four children, Phoebe, Brom, Esmé and Julia, and their friends.

> Frances did not eat her egg.  
> She sang a little song to it.  
> She sang the song very softly:  
>   
> "I do not like the way you slide,  
> I do not like your soft inside,  
> I do not like you lots of ways,  
> And I could do for many days  
> Without eggs."[[6]](#cite_note-Bread_and_Jam_for_Frances-6)

[Garth Williams](/wiki/Garth_Williams "Garth Williams") depicted Frances as a [badger](/wiki/Badger "Badger") in the first book, *Bedtime for Frances* (Harper, 1960), and Lillian Hoban retained that image as the illustrator of five sequels and a poetry collection, published from 1964 to 1972.[[3]](#cite_note-weber-3)[[5]](#cite_note-LCC-5)

The U.S. national library reports holding about three dozen books written by Hoban and published from 1959 to 1972, including about two dozen illustrated by Lillian Hoban. One was illustrated by their son Brom Hoban: *The Sea-thing Child* (1972).[[7]](#cite_note-LCC-brom-7)

A dark philosophical tale for older children, *[The Mouse and His Child](/wiki/The_Mouse_and_His_Child "The Mouse and His Child")*, appeared in 1967 and was Hoban's first full-length novel. It was later made into an animated film in 1977 by [Murakami-Wolf-Swenson](/wiki/Fred_Wolf_Films "Fred Wolf Films").

In 1969, the Hobans and their children travelled to [London](/wiki/London "London"), intending to stay only a short time. The marriage dissolved and, while the rest of the family returned to the United States, Hoban remained in London for the rest of his life. All of Hoban's adult novels except for *[Riddley Walker](/wiki/Riddley_Walker "Riddley Walker")*, *[Pilgermann](/wiki/Pilgermann "Pilgermann")*, *Angelica Lost and Found* (October 2010) and *Fremder* are set either wholly or partly in contemporary London.

In 1971, Hoban wrote a book employing concepts borrowed from "[The Gift of the Magi](/wiki/The_Gift_of_the_Magi "The Gift of the Magi")", called *[Emmet Otter's Jug-Band Christmas](/wiki/Emmet_Otter%27s_Jug-Band_Christmas_(book) "Emmet Otter's Jug-Band Christmas (book)")*, which further reached fans through a [1977 television special](/wiki/Emmet_Otter%27s_Jug-Band_Christmas_(TV_program) "Emmet Otter's Jug-Band Christmas (TV program)") originally created for HBO by the [Jim Henson Company](/wiki/Jim_Henson "Jim Henson"). The book was illustrated by Lillian Hoban, whose drawn renditions of these characters were faithfully replicated by the Muppet creators. The story tells of a poor otter mother and son who do what they must to try to provide a special Christmas to one another, taking a route neither of them expected. His novel *Turtle Diary* (1975) was turned into [a film version](/wiki/Turtle_Diary "Turtle Diary") released in 1985, with a screenplay by [Harold Pinter](/wiki/Harold_Pinter "Harold Pinter").

Family
------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Russell_Hoban&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Family")]

Hoban had four children with his first wife, [Lillian Aberman Hoban](/wiki/Lillian_Hoban "Lillian Hoban"). Their daughter [Phoebe Hoban](/wiki/Phoebe_Hoban "Phoebe Hoban") is a journalist and biographer who specializes in art.[[8]](#cite_note-8) The couple divorced in 1975, and in the same year he married Gundula Ahl, who worked in the fashionable London bookshop [Truslove and Hanson](/wiki/Truslove_and_Hanson "Truslove and Hanson").[[9]](#cite_note-Wroe-9) With Ahl he had three children,[[2]](#cite_note-telegraph-2) one of whom is the composer [Wieland Hoban](/w/index.php?title=Wieland_Hoban&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wieland Hoban (page does not exist)"),[[9]](#cite_note-Wroe-9) to whom *Riddley Walker* is dedicated. Wieland Hoban set one of his father's texts to music in his piece *Night Roads* (1998–99).

Hoban's sister, [Tana Hoban](/wiki/Tana_Hoban "Tana Hoban") (1917–2006), was a photographer and children's author;[[10]](#cite_note-10) he also had another sister, [Freeda Hoban Ellis](/w/index.php?title=Freeda_Hoban_Ellis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Freeda Hoban Ellis (page does not exist)") (1919–2002).

Later life
----------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Russell_Hoban&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Later life")]

The last of Hoban's novels published during his lifetime was *Angelica Lost and Found* (October 2010), in which the [hippogriff](/wiki/Hippogriff "Hippogriff") from [Girolamo da Carpi](/wiki/Girolamo_da_Carpi "Girolamo da Carpi")'s *[Ruggiero](/wiki/Ruggiero_(character) "Ruggiero (character)") Saving [Angelica](/wiki/Angelica_(character) "Angelica (character)")* breaks free from the 16th-century painting to search for Angelica in 21st-century [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco").

Hoban died on 13 December 2011.[[1]](#cite_note-flood-1) He had once ruefully observed that death would be a good career move: "People will say, 'Yes, Hoban, he seems an interesting writer, let's look at him again'."[[9]](#cite_note-Wroe-9)

Two new Hoban books were published posthumously by Walker Books in 2012: *[Soonchild](/wiki/Soonchild "Soonchild")*, illustrated by Alexis Deacon,[[11]](#cite_note-11) and *Rosie's Magic Horse*, illustrated by [Quentin Blake](/wiki/Quentin_Blake "Quentin Blake").[[12]](#cite_note-rmh-12) Deacon also provided artwork for a new version of *Jim's Lion*, published in 2014, which changed the format from a traditional picture book to a combination of text chapters and comics.[[13]](#cite_note-13)[[14]](#cite_note-14)

After his death, Hoban's papers were archived by writer Paul Cooper,[[15]](#cite_note-15) and in 2016 the archive was acquired by the [Beinecke Library](/wiki/Beinecke_Library "Beinecke Library") at [Yale University](/wiki/Yale_University "Yale University").[[16]](#cite_note-16)[[17]](#cite_note-17)

Fan and community activity
--------------------------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Russell_Hoban&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Fan and community activity")]

In May 1998, [Dave Awl](/w/index.php?title=Dave_Awl&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dave Awl (page does not exist)"), a writer/performer with the experimental Chicago theatre troupe the [Neo-Futurists](/wiki/Neo-Futurists "Neo-Futurists"), launched the first comprehensive Russell Hoban reference website,[[18]](#cite_note-18)[[19]](#cite_note-19)[[20]](#cite_note-20) The Head of Orpheus, to which Russell Hoban regularly contributed news and information up until his death. In the fall of 1999, Awl founded a Hoban-themed online community called The Kraken (named after one of the characters in Hoban's 1987 novel [The Medusa Frequency](/wiki/The_Medusa_Frequency "The Medusa Frequency")), which grew into an international network of Russell Hoban fans.

In 2002 an annual fan activity dubbed the Slickman A4 Quotation Event (SA4QE) (named after its founder, Diana Slickman, also a member of the Neo-Futurists) began, in which Hoban enthusiasts celebrate his birthday by writing down favourite quotes from his books (invariably on sheets of yellow A4 paper, a recurring Hoban motif) and leaving them in public places.[[9]](#cite_note-Wroe-9)
By 2004, the event had occurred three times;[[21]](#cite_note-Hanks-21) as of February 2011 it has since taken place each year, seeing over 350 quotes distributed around 46 towns and cities throughout 14 countries.[[22]](#cite_note-SA4QE-22)

In 2005 fans from across the world celebrated Hoban's work in London at the first international convention for the author, *The Russell Hoban Some-Poasyum* (a pun on [symposium](/wiki/Symposium "Symposium") from *Riddley Walker*).[[23]](#cite_note-Merritt-23) A booklet was published by the organisers to commemorate the event featuring tributes to Hoban from a variety of contributors including actor and politician [Glenda Jackson](/wiki/Glenda_Jackson "Glenda Jackson"), novelist [David Mitchell](/wiki/David_Mitchell_(author) "David Mitchell (author)"), composer [Harrison Birtwistle](/wiki/Harrison_Birtwistle "Harrison Birtwistle") and screenwriter [Andrew Davies](/wiki/Andrew_Davies_(writer) "Andrew Davies (writer)").

In 2012 a new "official" Russell Hoban website, [www.russellhoban.org](http://www.russellhoban.org), was built and launched by volunteers from the community, with the approval of the author's family.[[24]](#cite_note-24)

Stage adaptations
-----------------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Russell_Hoban&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Stage adaptations")]

In 1984, Hoban collaborated with the [Impact Theatre Co-operative](/wiki/Impact_Theatre_Co-operative "Impact Theatre Co-operative") on a performance entitled *The Carrier Frequency*. Hoban supplied the text for the piece, which was staged and performed by Impact. In 1999, *The Carrier Frequency* was restaged by the theater company [Stan's Cafe](/wiki/Stan%27s_Cafe "Stan's Cafe").[[25]](#cite_note-25)[[26]](#cite_note-The_Head_of_Orpheus-26)

In February 1986, a theatrical version of Hoban's novel *Riddley Walker* (adapted by Hoban himself) premiered at the [Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester](/wiki/Royal_Exchange_Theatre,_Manchester "Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester"). Its US premiere was at the [Chocolate Bayou Theatre](/w/index.php?title=Chocolate_Bayou_Theatre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chocolate Bayou Theatre (page does not exist)"), in April 1987, directed by Greg Roach.[[26]](#cite_note-The_Head_of_Orpheus-26)

In November 2007, Hoban's adaptation of *Riddley Walker* was produced (for the third time) by the [Red Kettle Theatre Company](/wiki/Red_Kettle_Theatre_Company "Red Kettle Theatre Company"), in [Waterford](/wiki/Waterford "Waterford"), Ireland, and was reviewed favorably in the *[Irish Times](/wiki/The_Irish_Times "The Irish Times")*.[[27]](#cite_note-27)[[28]](#cite_note-Munster_Express-28)

In March 1989 a stage adaptation of *[Kleinzeit](/wiki/Kleinzeit "Kleinzeit")* was presented by the [Tower Theatre Company](/wiki/Tower_Theatre_Company "Tower Theatre Company"), directed by Peta Barker, who had adapted the novel. One performance was seen by Russell Hoban who wrote a critique of the play, written on yellow paper, which is a major theme of the novel.

In 2011, the Trouble Puppet Theater Company produced an adaptation of *Riddley Walker*, with permission from and the aid of Russell Hoban. Artistic Director Connor Hopkins created the puppet theater play, with performances September 29 through October 16, 2011, at Salvage Vanguard Theater in Austin, Texas, U.S.[[29]](#cite_note-29) The production employed tabletop puppetry inspired by the [Bunraku](/wiki/Bunraku "Bunraku") tradition and enjoyed popular and critical success.[[30]](#cite_note-30)

In 2012, the [Royal Shakespeare Company](/wiki/Royal_Shakespeare_Company "Royal Shakespeare Company") announced that it would be premiering a new staging of Hoban's novel *The Mouse and His Child* as part of its winter 2012–13 season.[[31]](#cite_note-31)

Themes
------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Russell_Hoban&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Themes")]

Hoban is often described as a fantasy writer, and only two of his novels, *Turtle Diary* and *The Bat Tattoo*, are entirely devoid of supernatural elements. However, the fantasy elements are usually presented as only moderately surprising developments in an otherwise realistic contemporary story, which is [magic realism](/wiki/Magic_realism "Magic realism"). Exceptions include *Kleinzeit*, a comic fantasy whose characters include [Death](/wiki/Death "Death"), [Hospital](/wiki/Hospital "Hospital"), and [Underground](/wiki/London_Underground "London Underground");[[9]](#cite_note-Wroe-9) *Riddley Walker*, a science-fiction novel whose futuristic setting is primitive and post-apocalyptic; *Pilgermann*, a historical novel about the [Crusades](/wiki/Crusade "Crusade"); and *Fremder*, a more conventional science-fiction novel. [*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

There is frequent repetition of images and themes in different contexts. For instance, many of Hoban's works refer to [lions](/wiki/Lion "Lion"), [Orpheus](/wiki/Orpheus "Orpheus"), [Eurydice](/wiki/Eurydice "Eurydice"), [Persephone](/wiki/Persephone "Persephone"), [Vermeer](/wiki/Vermeer "Vermeer"), [severed heads](/wiki/Decapitation "Decapitation"), [heart disease](/wiki/Coronary_heart_disease "Coronary heart disease"), [flickering](/wiki/Persistence_of_vision "Persistence of vision"), [Odilon Redon](/wiki/Odilon_Redon "Odilon Redon"), and [King Kong](/wiki/King_Kong "King Kong").[[2]](#cite_note-telegraph-2)

Awards
------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Russell_Hoban&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Awards")]

*How Tom Beat Captain Najork and His Hired Sportsmen* (1974), a [picture book](/wiki/Picture_book "Picture book") written by Hoban, illustrated by [Quentin Blake](/wiki/Quentin_Blake "Quentin Blake"), and published by [Jonathan Cape](/wiki/Jonathan_Cape "Jonathan Cape"), shared the [annual Whitbread Award](/wiki/1974_Whitbread_Awards "1974 Whitbread Awards") for Children's Books.[[9]](#cite_note-Wroe-9)

*[Riddley Walker](/wiki/Riddley_Walker "Riddley Walker")*, a novel published by Cape in 1980, won the 1982 [John W. Campbell Memorial Award for Best Science Fiction Novel](/wiki/John_W._Campbell_Memorial_Award_for_Best_Science_Fiction_Novel "John W. Campbell Memorial Award for Best Science Fiction Novel"), juried recognition of the year's best SF novel published in English, and the "Best International Novel" prize at the 1983 Australian SF Convention ([Ditmar Award](/wiki/Ditmar_Award "Ditmar Award")).[[32]](#cite_note-SFawards-hoban-32) *[Pilgermann](/wiki/Pilgermann "Pilgermann")* was one finalist a year later when no best international novel was named.[[32]](#cite_note-SFawards-hoban-32)

**Karen Louise Erdrich** ([/ˈɜːrdrɪk/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*ER-drik*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key");[[2]](#cite_note-2) born June 7, 1954)[[3]](#cite_note-Stookey1999-3) is a [Native American](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the United States") author of novels, poetry, and children's books featuring Native American characters and settings. She is an enrolled citizen of the [Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians of North Dakota](/wiki/Turtle_Mountain_Band_of_Chippewa_Indians_of_North_Dakota "Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians of North Dakota"), a [federally recognized](/wiki/Federally_recognized "Federally recognized") [Ojibwe people](/wiki/Ojibwe_people "Ojibwe people").[[4]](#cite_note-4)[[1]](#cite_note-davies-1)

Erdrich is widely acclaimed as one of the most significant writers of the second wave of the [Native American Renaissance](/wiki/Native_American_Renaissance "Native American Renaissance"). She has written 28 books in all, including fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and children's books. In 2009, her novel *[The Plague of Doves](/wiki/The_Plague_of_Doves_(novel) "The Plague of Doves (novel)")* was a finalist for the [Pulitzer Prize for Fiction](/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Fiction "Pulitzer Prize for Fiction") and received an [Anisfield-Wolf Book Award](/wiki/Anisfield-Wolf_Book_Award "Anisfield-Wolf Book Award").[[5]](#cite_note-anisfield-wolf-5) In November 2012, she received the [National Book Award for Fiction](/wiki/National_Book_Award_for_Fiction "National Book Award for Fiction") for her novel *[The Round House](/wiki/The_Round_House_(novel) "The Round House (novel)")*.[[6]](#cite_note-nyt2012-6) She is a 2013 recipient of the [Alex Awards](/wiki/Alex_Awards "Alex Awards"). She was awarded the [Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction](/wiki/Library_of_Congress_Prize_for_American_Fiction "Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction") at the [National Book Festival](/wiki/National_Book_Festival "National Book Festival") in September 2015.[[7]](#cite_note-alter-7) In 2021, she was awarded the [Pulitzer Prize for Fiction](/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Fiction "Pulitzer Prize for Fiction") for her novel *[The Night Watchman](/wiki/The_Night_Watchman_(novel) "The Night Watchman (novel)")*.[[8]](#cite_note-8)

She was married to author [Michael Dorris](/wiki/Michael_Dorris "Michael Dorris") and the two collaborated on a number of works. The couple separated in 1995 and then divorced in 1996; Dorris would also take his own life in 1997 as allegations that he sexually abused at least three of the daughters whom he raised with Erdrich were under investigation.[[9]](#cite_note-dorris-9)[[10]](#cite_note-dorrisaccused-10)[[11]](#cite_note-divorceandaccusations-11)

She is also the owner of [Birchbark Books](/wiki/Birchbark_Books "Birchbark Books"), a small [independent bookstore](/wiki/Independent_bookstore "Independent bookstore") in [Minneapolis](/wiki/Minneapolis "Minneapolis") that focuses on Native American literature and the Native community in the Twin Cities.[[12]](#cite_note-12)

Personal life
-------------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Louise_Erdrich&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Personal life")]

Erdrich was born on June 7, 1954, in [Little Falls, Minnesota](/wiki/Little_Falls,_Minnesota "Little Falls, Minnesota"). She was the oldest of seven children born to Ralph Erdrich, a German-American, and Rita (née Gourneau), an Ojibwe woman of French descent.[[13]](#cite_note-13) Both parents taught at a boarding school in [Wahpeton, North Dakota](/wiki/Wahpeton,_North_Dakota "Wahpeton, North Dakota"), set up by the [Bureau of Indian Affairs](/wiki/Bureau_of_Indian_Affairs "Bureau of Indian Affairs"). Erdrich's maternal grandfather, Patrick Gourneau, served as tribal chairman for the federally recognized tribe of [Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians](/wiki/Turtle_Mountain_Band_of_Chippewa_Indians "Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians") for many years.[[14]](#cite_note-14) Though not raised in a reservation, she often visited relatives there.[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15) She was raised "with all the accepted truths" of Catholicism.[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15)

While Erdrich was a child, her father paid her a nickel for every story she wrote. Her sister Heidi became a poet and also lives in Minnesota; she publishes under the name [Heid E. Erdrich](/wiki/Heid_E._Erdrich "Heid E. Erdrich").[[16]](#cite_note-16) Their sister Lise Erdrich has written children's books and collections of fiction and essays.[[17]](#cite_note-17)

Erdrich attended [Dartmouth College](/wiki/Dartmouth_College "Dartmouth College") from 1972 to 1976.[[18]](#cite_note-Louise_Erdrich_2010-18) She was a part of the first class of women admitted to the college and earned a B.A. in English. During her first year, Erdrich met [Michael Dorris](/wiki/Michael_Dorris "Michael Dorris"), an [anthropologist](/wiki/Anthropologist "Anthropologist"), writer, and then-director of the new Native American Studies program. While attending Dorris' class, she began to look into her own ancestry, which inspired her to draw from it for her literary work, such as poems, short stories, and novels. During that time, she worked as a lifeguard, waitress, researcher for films,[[19]](#cite_note-:1-19) and as an editor for the Boston Indian Council newspaper *The Circle.*[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15)

In 1978, Erdrich enrolled in a Master of Arts program at [Johns Hopkins University](/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University "Johns Hopkins University") in [Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore"), Maryland. She earned the Master of Arts in the Writing Seminars in 1979.[[18]](#cite_note-Louise_Erdrich_2010-18) Erdrich later published some of the poems and stories she wrote while in the M.A. program. She returned to Dartmouth as a writer-in-residence.[[18]](#cite_note-Louise_Erdrich_2010-18)

After graduating from Dartmouth, Erdrich remained in contact with Dorris. He attended one of her poetry readings, became impressed with her work, and developed an interest in working with her.[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15) Although Erdrich and Dorris were on two different sides of the world, Erdrich in Boston and Dorris in New Zealand for field research, the two began to collaborate on short stories.

The pair's literary partnership led them to a romantic relationship. They married in 1981, and raised three children whom Dorris had adopted as a single parent (Reynold Abel, Madeline, and Sava[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15)) and three biological children together (Persia, Pallas, and Aza Marion[[20]](#cite_note-:2-20)). Reynold Abel suffered from fetal alcohol syndrome and in 1991, at age 23, he was killed when he was hit by a car.[[21]](#cite_note-21) In 1995, their son Sava accused Dorris of committing child abuse;[[22]](#cite_note-22) in 1997, after Dorris' death, his adopted daughter Madeline claimed that Dorris had sexually abused her and Erdrich had neglected to stop the abuse.[[23]](#cite_note-:3-23)

Dorris and Erdrich separated in 1995,[[9]](#cite_note-dorris-9) and would divorce in 1996.[[11]](#cite_note-divorceandaccusations-11) Dorris, who was accused of sexually abusing two of the biological daughters he had with Erdrich,[[10]](#cite_note-dorrisaccused-10) died by suicide in 1997. In his will, he omitted Erdrich and his adopted children Sava and Madeline;[[23]](#cite_note-:3-23) Madeline accused Dorris of sexually abusing her as well.[[9]](#cite_note-dorris-9)

In 2001, at age 47, Erdrich gave birth to a daughter, Azure, whose Native American father Erdrich declines to identify publicly.[[24]](#cite_note-24) She discusses her pregnancy with Azure, and Azure's father, in her 2003 nonfiction book, *Books and Islands in Ojibwe Country*.[[25]](#cite_note-:4-25) She uses the name "Tobasonakwut" to refer to him.[[26]](#cite_note-:5-26)[[27]](#cite_note-27) He is described as a traditional healer and teacher, who is eighteen years Erdrich's senior and a married man.[[26]](#cite_note-:5-26)[[25]](#cite_note-:4-25) In a number of publications, Tobasonakwut Kinew, who died in 2012, is referred to as Erdrich's partner and the father of Azure.[[28]](#cite_note-28)

When asked in an interview if writing is a lonely life for her, Erdrich replied, "Strangely, I think it is. I am surrounded by an abundance of family and friends and yet I am alone with the writing. And that is perfect." Erdrich lives in [Minneapolis](/wiki/Minneapolis "Minneapolis").[[29]](#cite_note-Interview-29)

Work
----

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Louise_Erdrich&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Work")]

In 1979, she wrote "The World's Greatest Fisherman",[[30]](#cite_note-30) a short story about June Kashpaw, a divorced Ojibwe woman whose death by [hypothermia](/wiki/Hypothermia "Hypothermia") brought her relatives home to a fictional North Dakota reservation for her funeral. She wrote this while "barricaded in the kitchen."[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15) At her husband's urging, she submitted it to the Nelson Algren Short Fiction competition in 1982 for which it won the $5,000 prize,[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15) and eventually it became the first chapter of her debut novel, *[Love Medicine](/wiki/Love_Medicine "Love Medicine")*, published by [Holt, Rinehart, and Winston](/wiki/Holt,_Rinehart,_and_Winston "Holt, Rinehart, and Winston") in 1984.[[29]](#cite_note-Interview-29)

"When I found out about the prize I was living on a farm in New Hampshire near the college I'd attended," Erdrich told an interviewer. "I was nearly broke and driving a car with bald tires. My mother knitted my sweaters, and all else I bought at thrift stores ... The recognition dazzled me. Later, I became friends with [Studs Terkel](/wiki/Studs_Terkel "Studs Terkel") and [Kay Boyle](/wiki/Kay_Boyle "Kay Boyle"), the judges, toward whom I carry a lifelong gratitude. This prize made an immense difference in my life."[[31]](#cite_note-31)

*Love Medicine* won the 1984 National Book Critics Circle Award.[[32]](#cite_note-Author:_Louise_Erdrich-32) It is the only debut novel ever to receive that honor.[[33]](#cite_note-33) Erdrich later turned *Love Medicine* into a tetralogy that includes *The Beet Queen* (1986), *[Tracks](/wiki/Tracks_(novel) "Tracks (novel)")* (1988), and *[The Bingo Palace](/wiki/The_Bingo_Palace "The Bingo Palace")* (1994). It has also been featured on the National [Advanced Placement](/wiki/Advanced_Placement "Advanced Placement") Test for Literature.[[34]](#cite_note-34)

In the early years of their marriage, Erdrich and Michael Dorris often collaborated on their work, saying they plotted the books together, "talk about them before any writing is done, and then we share almost every day, whatever it is we've written" but "the person whose name is on the books is the one who's done most of the primary writing.[[19]](#cite_note-:1-19)" They got started with "domestic, romantic stuff" published under the shared pen name of "Milou North" (Michael + Louise + where they live).[[15]](#cite_note-:0-15)

During the publication of *Love Medicine*, Erdrich produced her first collection of poems, *Jacklight* (1984), which highlights the struggles between Native and non-Native cultures, as well as celebrating family, ties of kinship, autobiographical meditations, monologues, and love poetry. She incorporates elements of Ojibwe myths and legends.[[18]](#cite_note-Louise_Erdrich_2010-18) Erdrich continues to write poems, which have been included in her collections.

Erdrich is best known as a novelist, and has published a dozen award-winning and best-selling novels.[[18]](#cite_note-Louise_Erdrich_2010-18) She followed *Love Medicine* with *The Beet Queen* (1986), which continued her technique of using [multiple narrators](/wiki/Multiperspectivity "Multiperspectivity")[[35]](#cite_note-35) and expanded the fictional reservation universe of *Love Medicine* to include the nearby town of Argus, North Dakota. The action of the novel takes place mostly before [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). [Leslie Marmon Silko](/wiki/Leslie_Marmon_Silko "Leslie Marmon Silko") accused Erdrich's *The Beet Queen* of being more concerned with [postmodern](/wiki/Postmodern_literature "Postmodern literature") technique than with the political struggles of Native peoples.[[36]](#cite_note-36)

*[Tracks](/wiki/Tracks_(novel) "Tracks (novel)")* (1988) goes back to the early 20th century at the formation of the reservation. It introduces the [trickster](/wiki/Trickster "Trickster") figure of Nanapush, who owes a clear debt to Ojibwe figure [Nanabozho](/wiki/Nanabozho "Nanabozho").[[37]](#cite_note-37) There are many studies of the trickster figure in Erdrich's novels. *Tracks* shows early clashes between traditional ways and the [Roman Catholic Church](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church "Roman Catholic Church"). *[The Bingo Palace](/wiki/The_Bingo_Palace_(Novel) "The Bingo Palace (Novel)")* (1994), set in the 1980s, describes the effects of a casino and a factory on the reservation community. *Tales of Burning Love* (1997) finishes the story of Sister Leopolda, a recurring character from all the previous books, and introduces a new set of European-American people into the reservation universe.

*The Antelope Wife* (1998), Erdrich's first novel after her divorce from Dorris, was the first of her novels to be set outside the continuity of the previous books.[[3]](#cite_note-Stookey1999-3) Erdrich heavily revised the book in 2009 and published the revision as *The Antelope Woman* in 2016.[[38]](#cite_note-38)

She subsequently returned to the reservation and nearby towns. She has published five novels since 1998 dealing with events in that fictional area. Among these are *[The Last Report on the Miracles at Little No Horse](/wiki/Last_Report_on_the_Miracles_at_Little_No_Horse "Last Report on the Miracles at Little No Horse")* (2001) and *[The Master Butchers Singing Club](/wiki/The_Master_Butchers_Singing_Club "The Master Butchers Singing Club")* (2003). Both novels have geographic and character connections with *The Beet Queen*. In 2009, Erdrich was a [Pulitzer Prize](/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Fiction "Pulitzer Prize for Fiction") finalist for *[The Plague of Doves](/wiki/The_Plague_of_Doves_(novel) "The Plague of Doves (novel)")*[[39]](#cite_note-39) and a National Book Award finalist for *[The Last Report on the Miracles at Little No Horse](/wiki/The_Last_Report_on_the_Miracles_at_Little_No_Horse "The Last Report on the Miracles at Little No Horse")*.[[40]](#cite_note-40) *The Plague of Doves* focuses on the historical lynching of four Native people wrongly accused of murdering a White family, and the effect of this injustice on the following generations. Her Pulitzer Prize–winning novel *[The Night Watchman](/wiki/The_Night_Watchman_(novel) "The Night Watchman (novel)")*[[41]](#cite_note-41) (2020) concerns a campaign to defeat the 'termination bill' (introduced by Senator [Arthur Vivian Watkins](/wiki/Arthur_Vivian_Watkins "Arthur Vivian Watkins")), and Erdrich acknowledged her sources and its inspiration being her maternal grandfather's life.[[42]](#cite_note-42) Her most recent novel, *[The Sentence](/wiki/The_Sentence_(novel) "The Sentence (novel)")*, tells the fictional story of a haunting at Erdrich's Minneapolis bookstore, set against the backdrop of the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic"), [George Floyd's murder](/wiki/Murder_of_George_Floyd "Murder of George Floyd"), and the [resulting protests](/wiki/George_Floyd_protests "George Floyd protests").[[43]](#cite_note-43)

She also writes for younger audiences; she has a children's picture book *Grandmother's Pigeon,* and her children's book *[The Birchbark House](/wiki/The_Birchbark_House "The Birchbark House")*, was a National Book Award finalist.[[44]](#cite_note-44) She continued the series with *[The Game of Silence](/wiki/The_Game_of_Silence "The Game of Silence")*, winner of the Scott O'Dell Award for Historical Fiction,[[45]](#cite_note-45) *[The Porcupine Year](/wiki/The_Porcupine_Year "The Porcupine Year")*, *[Chickadee](/wiki/Chickadee_(novel) "Chickadee (novel)")*, and *Makoons*.

### Nonfiction and teaching

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Louise_Erdrich&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Nonfiction and teaching")]

In addition to fiction and poetry, Erdrich has published nonfiction. *The Blue Jay's Dance* (1995) is about her pregnancy and the birth of her third child.[[46]](#cite_note-46) *Books and Islands in Ojibwe Country* (2003) traces her travels in northern Minnesota and Ontario's lakes following the birth of her youngest daughter.[[47]](#cite_note-47)

### Influence and style

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Louise_Erdrich&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Influence and style")]

Her heritage from both parents is influential in her life and prominent in her work.[[48]](#cite_note-48) Although many of Erdrich's works explore her Native American heritage, her novel *[The Master Butchers Singing Club](/wiki/The_Master_Butchers_Singing_Club "The Master Butchers Singing Club")* (2003) featured the European, specifically German, side of her ancestry. The novel includes stories of a [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") veteran of the German Army and is set in a small North Dakota town.[[49]](#cite_note-49) The novel was a finalist for the National Book Award.

Erdrich's interwoven series of novels have drawn comparisons with [William Faulkner](/wiki/William_Faulkner "William Faulkner")'s [Yoknapatawpha](/wiki/Yoknapatawpha "Yoknapatawpha") novels. Like Faulkner's, Erdrich's successive novels created multiple narratives in the same fictional area and combined the tapestry of local history with current themes and modern consciousness.[[50]](#cite_note-50)

Birchbark Books
---------------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Louise_Erdrich&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Birchbark Books")]

Main article: [Birchbark Books](/wiki/Birchbark_Books "Birchbark Books")

Erdrich's bookstore hosts literary readings and other events. Her new works are read here, and events celebrate the works and careers of other writers as well, particularly local Native writers. Erdrich and her staff consider Birchbark Books to be a "teaching bookstore".[[51]](#cite_note-birchbarkbooks1-51) In addition to books, the store sells [Native American art](/wiki/Native_American_art "Native American art") and traditional medicines, and Native American jewelry. Wiigwaas Press, a small nonprofit publisher founded by Erdrich and her sister, is affiliated with the store.[[51]](#cite_note-birchbarkbooks1-51)
